body.p:
Maysville Kentucky
November 12th 1863
To his Excellency
Gov Bramlette

Dear Sir, At the late term of the Mason Circuit Court, I was fined for selling spiritous liquors to a slave, whose an agreed statement of facts, a copy of which together with a Copy of the judgment I enclose. I have kept a Bar in Maysville for a number of years, and have always endeavored to comply with the strict letter and spirit of the law. I knew that I had no right to sell liquor to a slave and always refused to do so without the permission of the master. I knew the boy to whom the liquor in this instance was sold, to be the slave of my neighbor Samuel W Wood, but I knew that he was hired to a free negro barber who also kept a shop a few doors from me. The negro boy came in with the barber to whom he was hired, and his temporary master told me to let him have a drink of whiskey, and supposing I had a right to do so under this authority I sold the boy a drink for himself and his temporary master. Poliltical excitement was bitter at the time and I was indicted for selling, although s w wood cared nothing about the matter, and although it was the only drink the boy ever took at my bar. I respectfully required your excellency to remit so much of the fine as by law you are permitted to do, as the balance makes a sum as large as I am able to pay

Mason Cir Ct
vs
Peter Miller
$50 --
Tipling
16th Nov 1863

Remit except fees & costs
Tho E Bramlette
